title: 104_s1372
content: The Act titled "Senior Citizens' Freedom to Work Act" adjusts the monthly exempt amount for the Social Security earnings test. The "Senior Citizens' Freedom to Work Act" increases the monthly exempt amount for individuals who have attained retirement age under the Social Security Act. The "Senior Citizens' Freedom to Work Act" increases the monthly exempt amount for individuals who have attained retirement age under the Social Security Act to $1,875.00 for each month ending after 1998 and before 2000, $2,083.33\1/3\ for each month ending after 1999 and before 2001, $2,291.66\2/3\ for each month ending after 2000 and before 2002, and $2,500.00 for each month ending after 2001 and before 2003. The amounts are subject to a cost-of-living adjustment after 2002. The amendments made by this subsection increase the monthly exempt amount for individuals who have attained retirement age under the Social Security Act. The amendments apply to taxable years beginning after 1995. The Social Security Act is amended to increase the rate of interest for the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund for obligations issued between September 30, 1995, and October 1, 2002, by .25 percent point for each fiscal year beginning after 1995. The Social Security Act is amended to increase the rate of interest for the Federal Old-Age and Survivors Insurance Trust Fund for obligations issued between September 30, 1995, and October 1, 2002, by .25 percent point for each fiscal year beginning after 1995. The amendments made by this subsection shall apply with respect to obligations issued after December 31, 1995. Additionally, each nonexempt account within the discretionary spending category for each of the fiscal years 1996 through 2002 may be reduced by a uniform percentage if necessary. The Social Security Act may require reductions to offset Trust Fund shortfall resulting from amendments. Reductions to be implemented by Presidential order to eliminate budget-year breach. GAO to report on the Act within 2 years of enactment. The Comptroller General of the United States will report to Congress on the dynamic effect of the reform of the social security earnings limit and its true effect on the Federal budget, within two years of the enactment of the Social Security Act.
